title: Do people in their 50s and 60s play video games? - Quora

response.answer_text: Full disclosure, I’m only 48 and something catastrophic may happen in the next two years that will make me stop playing video games. Yes they do, and the games they play are as wide and varied as anyone else; probably more so. See, I grew up when games were just games. It didn’t matter if what game you were playing, because we were jazzed about games in general. As time has gone on and gaming has become popular, the general public has sequestered games into neat cubicles so that they can feel superior about their preferences. That isn’t really the way it started out. No one was talking down to people who didn’t like the games that other people played, because they were all in the same general pool. That’s why my tastes in games covers nearly every genre and I have no interest in competition. We played games to play them, getting a high score was just a bonus, the joy was in the game play. There are so few games you can say that about these days because that love of the game has been stripped away by corporate greed and the idiocy that comes from a huge industry with no oversight and no accountability (that is changing now on a legal level and if you discover that your favorite games become illegal in your country, that’s what happens when there is a huge industry with no oversight or accountability). As of right now I have installed on my computer…Dex, Rime, No Man’s Sky, Psychonauts, 7 Days to Die, Broforce, The Guild of Dungeoneering, Diluvion, Abzu, Cognition, Borderlands (1, 2, Pre-Sequel and GOTY Enhanced Edition), Diablo II, Warcraft III, Grim Dawn, Hard Reset, Shadow Warrior (the Flying Wild Hog games), Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, Headlander, Into The Breach, Jotun, Transiter, Skyrim (both old-rim and SSE, some “must have mods” don’t translate over), Septera Core: Legacy of the Creator and Stardew Valley. I also own a PS3, PS2, XBOX, Gamecube, a PS Vita, a PSP, an N-Gage. A nintendo DS, 3DS, Gameboy Advance and Gameboy Color are all on my list, as are about 1300 games. The only reason I don’t have the current generation of consoles is because I haven’t seen anything that’s exclusive to a console that I was willing to fork out the money for. PS: I’m really looking forward to Cyberpunk 2077 and Psychonauts 2. PPS: No, I don’t really care for the current state of gaming or the publishers involved. I don’t think they have done anything but made games more popular while simultaneously making them more expensive and generic. PPPS: I don’t like most people either. PPPPS: Thanks for reading.

Ill be 70 next month. I played a version of Dungeons and Dragons, tank war, and flight simulator on the Plato computer terminals at the University of Illinois starting in 1972. I could not afford an Atari or TI computer when they first came out. I owned a Pong game, and traded it in on a Commodore Vic20. I replaced it with a Commodore 64. We would type in games from Compute’s Gazette each month, as well as using some purchased games on cassette tapes and later on floppies. I enjoyed Frogger and Miner 49er. The tunes are still earworms.I enjoyed Wolfenstein, a WW2 shooter which somehow ran on the Commodore. That was replaced with a series of PCs. I liked simulation games, such as Flight Simulator, railroad simulators, and simulation of WW2 submarine warfare. I found Sim City interesting. My child bought a couple of games in the 1990s such as Nintendo. I could not get into games such as Mario, with all the jumping around and hand eye coordination. I found some PC games of the 1990s and after to be disappointing, such as Leisure Suit Larry, where the only way to “win” was to buy a clue book, which told you to turn over a certain rock you would not notice, next to a path, to get a key you would need much farther alone in the game. I have seen something like that in a current military simulation, where you have a series of skirmishes with enemy troops in WW2, then get to a courtyard where you are outnumbered, overpowered and doomed. I expect there is something like the cluebook that tells you there is a weapon or secret passage you would never find. The PC games might have a linear script, such that you go to a club to meet someone, but if you return to it later, it is empty. They are nit rich worlds, where you can do as you please. I am not interested in multiplayer games, because I would have zero in common with the kids playing them, and in the multiplayer games of 1972 on the Plato system, you could not practice landing your F15 because someone would shoot you down. I would enjoy a one player detective or adventure game, a military, aviation, submarine, naval or space war simulation which did not require you to buy extra cost weapons or armor, and which did not have the required extra cost clue books. The Sims type of game is interesting as it relates to my interest in the question of whether our reality is itself simulated. I’m not that familiar with the advantages of today’s dedicated game machines, such as PlayStation and Xbox. My grown offspring gets a lot of enjoyment out of a Switch, and plays some version of Mario. I find Red Redemption 2 interesting, since it allows pretty free play unlike the linear script of some older games. I might buy an Xbox.

At 53 years old, I’ve been playing video games since the 70’s - pinball and other mechanically-based games before that. BUT, my father had me beat - he’d played pinball since the 50’s! When we got our first home video game (Magnavox Odyssey 2), in 1978, he played it as much as I did. But one night, I found a trick in one of the games we had, (Take the Money and Run). You could paralyze the other player when you realized that bumping you and your opponent into a maze wall reversed your controls. My father didn’t figure it out and was furious. He accused me of cheating on the stupid game, and never played that console again. It turned him off of video games, seemingly forever… Many years later, work demanded that my father obtain a PC. This would’ve been in 1993ish. He asked for my help, but was explicit: ‘I don’t want none of those silly-ass games!’ Yes, he still held a grudge. I managed to get his a cheap, but capable enough PC, and then (as things still mostly ran in DOS), I created a menu system that let him use numbered shortcuts to select his software. As I recall, the visible menu numbers ran from 1–9. I created an invisible ‘0’ option and filled it with the kind of games my military and history buff father would have enjoyed if he’d give them a chance. And waited… About 9 months later or so, I got a frantic call from my mother who demanded what I had done. I’d totally forgotten about the games menu! Here, my father had discovered the Gettysburg Civil War and Civilization games I’d loaded up for him. He’d taken two days off of work, saying he was sick, and mom said he’d hardly come out of the room! :) My dad justified it by telling me later that those games weren’t anything like those silly-ass arcade games I played. Well… Of course! I’d been trying to tell him that for a long, LONG time. But he still fumed at the memory of our last real game together. In the end, he was addicted and as time went on, he’d come to me for more and more updates to his machine. Better graphics, faster processors, more memory, etc. It was hilarious and exciting to him and I was truly happy he’d discovered that menu. Later when the grand-kids came along, he started playing strategy games over the Internet with them, teaching them along the way. My mother told me that dad had played Civilization IV until the day he died (cancer, in 2015). He was 71 years old. As for myself, at 53, I’m a little old to be playing the arcade or reflexive games the young flock to. I love The Long Dark, Elite Dangerous, and the Half Life Series (looking forward to getting VR and Half Life: Alyx next year!) One more note: You have to understand why people of my father’s generation were so resistant to arcade gaming. It was well known that many arcades and gaming companies were controlled, or associated with the mob. The mob enjoyed the fact that auditing machine like these was almost impossible and there was a LOT of money to be made. As a player, I saw NONE of this, but I have since read a lot about it. Attitudes changed a lot in the 80’s when games became more capable, and when computer/console gaming evolved away from arcades to the home. My father’s generation was still wary of the influences arcades might have on their kids.

I’m in my fifties, married with kids, and I play video games daily. Currently playing Skyrim, Cities Skylines and Sims 4 on PC, Red Dead Redemption 2 on the PlayStation and all sorts of stuff on phone and tablet. I played World of Warcraft and Guild Wars (the first one) for years, alongside probably hundreds of other games, many of whose names are lost to the mists of time. Young people seem to forget that those of us who seem incredibly old to them were playing games on our PCs, early consoles and whatever else before they were even born. You haven’t lived until you’ve laboured over creating the perfect autoexec.bat file to play (the original) Doom as smoothly as possible in DOS before booting Windows 3.1 and getting on with some work. And yes, I know there were earlier versions of Windows and much earlier video games. Fighting to get Doom running as well as I possibly could on my state-of-the-art 4MB (not a typo, young folk) RAM 486 is what I remember most vividly now, though.  Question: Do people in their 50s and 60s play video games?

I am a recently retired 65-year-old Silicon Valley software engineer who has spent his whole 40 years career developing software much like what underlies video games. I have worked for Apple, Adobe, eBay, Microsoft, VMWare, Cisco, etc. One of my bosses at Microsoft was the creator of Sim City. To date, the number of video games I have played is (drum roll) zero. My interest in video games is likewise zero. Do I think there is anything wrong with them? Nope. I’m just not interested for the same reason a first rate top-of-the-line French Chef wouldn’t eat in a McDonalds. There is no magic in them for me. I understand completely how they work. I have a M.S. in Computer Science from Texas A&M University specializing in AI. It seems like a complete and total waste of my skills to play a video game. It feels too much like menial lowly work.

I do. I bloody love my Switch, almost as much as I used to love my Intellivision. In fact, I play more than I ever did. Hooray!  The great benefits of getting older are: I can’t be bothered chasing skirt == more time to play.I can afford whatever games I like; no one can limit my ‘screen time’.I can afford whatever machine / console (or multiples thereof ) I like.. although Switch is the Queen!The doctor told me I gotta knock the cocaine on the head, so I no longer get angry when I lose.I have my own place, so I can play as loud and as late as I like.I can drink more Gin and my game doesn’t suffer for it.My reactions are not what they used to be, so it takes me longer to finish a game == better value for money.I appreciate “Enter The Gungeon” in a way someone younger than me cannot.I’m older than Mario, so that always makes me chuckle when playing Mario Karts (and I’m good at it… have been since version one. Ghost Valley— I can take anyone. It’s muscle memory.But— when I’m feeling low, I can still whip anyone I know at Lock n Chase.. ahh they don’t make ’em like they used to.:wq

I’m not in my 50s or 60s yet, but I’m not all that far from it either. I play video games. I have been playing video games for over three decades, since I first played Oregon Trail in elementary school. The first video game system I had was the original NES. Then I had a PC at home, and have been playing PC games ever since the days when they came on floppies. (I loved the bin of $5 games at Electronics Boutique.) I programmed and ran a MUD (text-based online game) before most people had any idea games could have multiple players. So I know a thing or two about them. I still play video games. I still like video games. I will be buying Kerbal Space Program 2 the day it comes out. Unless something catastrophic happens to me such that I literally cannot play them, I will absolutely still be playing them in my 50s, my 60s, and until the day they pull the keyboard from my cold, dead hands. And I am far from the only person I know for whom that is true.

Absolutely, when you reach that young age, you'll realise that your body may have aged a bit but your brain and whatever part of you makes you you, doesn't age. Me, I'm a very immature 51 year old man, although my wife often says I'm worse than the kids. I'm banned from shopping with my wife as I get bored quickly and cause mischief. My jokes are on par with any dad and I'm an avid gamer since Pong came out. I remember playing the Hobbit on our first PC and it would take an eternity for a picture to show up pixel by pixel. It was basically a RPG which you moved by compass directions and had commands such as take, unlock and such. Games just couldn't get any better. Fortunately games did get better, much better and so did the technology to play them with better graphics. And of course the internet. No instant access back in my day, oh no no. We got dial up first 33.6Kb/s now that was painful not to mention in the UK BT charged 1p a minute. Now that may not seem like a lit but when I used to play the original MechWarrior online it soon added up. Did I mention I was 51? I also have an Oculus Rift S VR headset which is awesome. And I cant wait for Half Life: Alyx to come out.  This is my current self build and I'm about to start modding an old case into a steampunk style with lots of copper and brass tubes etc. So next time you see a grumpy old fart like me out and about, though that could be a while away, try and imagine what games they might play? Stay safe everyone.

Yes we do. I grew up with games starting to appear on computers. First was the text based Adventure, then Moria, Rogue and a few others. Then came the early consoles that plugged into your TV - like pong, alien invaders etc. I skipped the whole handheld era, never got interested in that. Then came games on a PC. I worked on sound card device drivers for Windows - that supported 3D sound that games used. That eventually led to me joining a games company. So I worked on games for a brief four years. I still play them but never really got into gamepads. I prefer to use a keyboard and mouse. Even then, I’m left handed so I prefer games that let me use the arrow keys to move around. I tend to prefer Visual Novels, or exploration type games. Combat games, not so much, though Unreal Tournament was a fun one when I worked at the audio company. A group of us would play at lunchtime. I’m taking part in game jams too so I’ve not stopped working on games in my spare time.

“Do people in their 50s and 60s play video games?” Well, I’m creeping up on 48, so technically I’m not qualified to answer this. However… I’ve been playing video games since I was 8, when my dad brought home a Mattel Intellivision. Shortly thereafter, the arcade craze really took off, and I spent far more than my fair share of quarters on cabinet games. Since then, I’ve played regularly on, or owned, the following gaming devices: IntellivisionAtari 2600Commodore 64TurboGrafix 16PC (master race, baby)MacNESN64PS1PS2GamecubePS3WiiXbox 360DSPSPAndroidLinuxIn a couple of weeks, I will be receiving my 16-year badge on Steam. My library there is pushing 800 owned titles. As you might infer, I have no intention of stopping my enjoyment of one of the most (if not the most) cost-effective entertainment medium in the world, anytime soon. In other words: I’ll stop playing games when you pry my keyboard and mouse out of my cold, dead hands.

My dear man or woman, I will keep playing games as long as I can see the screen and handle the mouse. Gaming addict since 1986, I would have started sooner but there weren’t any capable machines available before that time. (Don’t bite my head off, capable for me started with the Atari 800. I also had a ZX81, I would not however call that a capable machine with 1K memory.)  After that twice a C64, on to the Amiga 1200 in 1993 and Windows PC starting 1998. Yes I play games, perhaps not the same as you do, not shooters.Cities Skylines, all RPG’s from Bioware, The Witcher 3, Heroes of the Storm.Steam list is too long to repeat here, over 60 AAA titles. Current hardware :Z97 Gaming 5, i7 4770K, 32 GB memory and a GTX 1070.Two of those machines standing side by side here as my partner also likes to game and I don’t want to share my machine.

Back in the 1980s video games were a new thing. And Old People don’t like new things. They like old things. And so, back in the 1980s old people didn’t play video games, young people did. They were a new thing, and young people like new things. The notion that video games are for kids made a certain amount of sense in the 1980s. It made a little bit of sense in the 1990s. It made very little sense in the 2000s. And it makes absolutely no sense in 2020. Video games have been around for 40 years. They are not a new thing. They are an old thing. There are old people like myself who have been playing video games for 40 years. Yes, video games are games. Kids like games. Kids like games such as baseball for instance. And when a kid who likes baseball grows up, they often still like baseball. You don’t get confused when you see an old guy at a baseball stadium, do you? You understand that old people can still like to watch grown men play a kid’s game like baseball.

The other day, I was playing Firewatch on my PC.  Before that, it was Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice.  I’ve been playing video games on the PC since ’95 and got my first console in 2006. I’m a Sony girl—my first console was a PS2. I still have it somewhere along with my two PSP’s. I have a PS3 and a PS4 and was just looking at the games available for my PS+ membership this month. I also have over 100 games on my Steam account. In addition to Steam, I often pick up free games from Epic and I play a few MMO’s here and there.  Before playing video games, I was an avid player of board games and card games. I played D&D in HS and college, although I was never DM and never had a desire to be. I also did an extensive study of video game design that involved breaking down design concepts in 100+ games. I went on to design some games that earned me some money even though they were never developed. I’m 55 and female.

A2A. Here’s my current roster of max-level characters on Eonar in World of Warcraft:  Ortin here is my main, a 120 boomkin. He’s a member of one of the top 5 raiding guilds on the server. I started playing WoW two weeks after release. When I’m not playing WoW, I play Skyrim, Fallout 4, and several real-time strategy games. I’d say about half the regular raiders in the guild are in their 40s or above. Yes, people in their 50s and 60s play video games.

This is Shirley Curry A.K.A the Gaming Grandma  She’s 80 years old and an absolute gem to watch as she streams some of her favorite games, particularly Skyrim. Gaming is at this point quite the old medium , the first videogames came out in the 60’s so that’s nearly 60 years of gaming history you can absolutely bet that there are some 50- 60 year old gamers out there or even as Shirley shows Gamers who are even older than that . She asks a great question , what does enjoying gaming have to do with youth ? We don’t ask if older people enjoy movies or music and yet when it comes to videogames there is supposed to be a barrier of appreciation . There are definitely 50 + year old gamers I have a few anecdotes but I think Shirley is perfect example of Gaming being an ageless medium that all can enjoy. Here’s Shirleys youtube channel Page
Yes. The over 50s make up around 8% of gamers. But they are more sought after by game developers because they have more time and money than younger gamers: Global gamers by age and gender | Statista

I'm sure there are many who do, especially if they played the games when they were younger. I know, I know. The idea that they used to be young AND there were video games back then can be totally shocking, but there you are. Home video games have been around since the mid 70's. Or at least, that's when I bought my sons an Atari. Yes, the graphics, action, and general upgrades are a far cry from the tennis game we began with, but stripped down, a video game is a video game.

Well. I'm 48 and am still an avid gamer. Red dead 2 has been in my xbox since 2018 and I'm only 3% off total completion. Have replayed the first Red dead for nostalgia recently as well. Just installed Jedi fallen order and will play ASAP. Have pre ordered star wars squadrons and am looking forward to kicking butt in multilayer. I've been a rebel pilot since the days of x wing alliance! I don't think gamers ever “grow out" of gaming. So long as the mind is sharp and the reflexes are quick we'll carry on until its just not possible. I fully intend to play into my 70's or 80's if I last that long.

Why wouldn’t we? When you get in from work why rinse your brain out with dumb TV when you can do something a bit more stimulating. I don’t know how old you are but I have probably been noodling with computers since before you were born. I was playing at landing on the moon with a programmable Texas Instruments caclulator at the age of 7, a mere 46 years ago. I wrote my own computer RPGs for the ZX Spectrum because the commercial ones got boring and samey very fast. So why stop now I am 53? As I said it beats watching TV when I get in from work. A hour or two pootling through distant stars in No Man’s Sky or Elite is as nice a way as any to chill out. The idea that we wouldn’t is a bit patronising really.

Do people in their 50s and 60s play video games? Sure we do! My wife and I both play World of Warcraft and Heroes of the Storm regularly with friends our age, as well as with younger (and sometimes older!) players. Ten years ago I raided with a woman in her 60’s. She’s still on my friends list, so I see she still plays regularly, and of course she’s now in her 70’s. We played D&D in our 20’s, and that was a fringe hobby back then. Forty years later, video games are everywhere, and players of all ages play them.

I'm not the I'm not the brightest thing on two feet but I'll tell you this I don't ever intend to play video games I know I haven't and I'm 81 but I do play too particular games on my smartphone that I hope are keeping me from going crazy where shall we saying too damn many senior moments talk together and that's free cell and the old style Solitaire with a Twist every game is winnable. Right now I have played 16500 games and I have won over 13500. That's 80% of the time with free cell it's between 90 and 95% of the time I win it's a tough game but nowhere as difficult as the solitaire

Yes..yes they do. I’ve been playing games since my first arcade trip when I was..oh…about 8…had one of the first home consoles (and pretty much every one after that with the exception of a few) ..and my trusty TRS-80 home computer in the beginning. Times have changed. Now I have a gaming PC and my PS4,…but I still play about 4 to 5 nights a week. I am in my 50’s, so my time to play has changed. I wait till the wife and kids go to bed, but i’ll be on about 9:30 or so at night and play until about 12:30 or so…

Damn straight we do, I've been playing the new season of Diablo III and doing pretty good. Ofcourse I'm on a 6 month vacation so I don't have to go out and work on my farm for a while. One of my neighbors kids comes over to look after things, I take care of his place when he's gone. So it works out for both of us.

Yup We are just older kids thats all. My wife is 55. I am 45. We spend an amazing amount of time in Ark Evolution and both Tom Clancy Divisions. Plus Ghost Recon, GTA, blah blah… Ya they do. A lot more than you think. In fact there is a HUGE whole in the gaming market right now for gamers over 40. Currently they are all being designed for age groups teen - adult. Hmmm, I wonder when they will figure that out? Thanks for the ask Game on!

Some do, some don't. My dad enjoyed playing video games when he was younger and he still does even though he is slightly over 50. When you think about it, someone who is now 50 was young adult during 90's, when some great games (that are now considered classics, like Civilization, Doom and TES Arena) came out. Many people (like my dad) who loved those games back then still enjoy video games today, which in my opinion, is exactly how it should be: As long as it doesn't hurt anyone, you shouldn't stop doing the things you love, no matter how old you are. (Also, thanks to this, I realized something scary: I'm almost as old now as my dad was back then!)

Hope it's ok to answer at 78yo. I play video games mostly on my phone and laptop. My techie husband wishes he'd never given me this neat phone! (Fanfare music) In the dawn of time there was Spacewar on a PDP. From that thru Tetris, with a great love of Gameboy, on to bubblex and similar on personal computers, currently hooked on ToonBlast a great phone game. Playing solitaire all thru. Life without video games, unthinkable! Is it time to check out Santaland?

Yes, but I’ve found they have particular tastes. My grandfather is probably in his early 60s, and he’s a fanatic for RTS games and World War 2 games of just about any genre. War is just in his nature, and he’s never even served. Actually, that may be why… But anyone in their 50s and 60s that I’ve seen playing video games tend to enjoy games that involves thinking and methodical action, not just mindless blitzing to victory like in Call of Duty, say.

Most of the time, people who play video games do so because they start at an earlier age. People in their 50’s and 60’s GENERALLY aren’t interested. I do know some though, and I’m sure there are some great articles on it that I don’t have the time to find at this moment. But in 20–40 years oh baby, we’ll all have to decide between our walkers or our controllers. And you better believe I’m goin down with the ship.

Oh yes we do! Just because you young whippersnappers don’t believe that we sit in gamers chairs that do nearly everything but cook or prepare your food and bring it to you. WE PLAY! The age range in the house here is 50–80. From baccarat to solitaire to POGO all day unless the mail carrier comes then we pause, and go and separate out the pieces of junk mail from the bills then get back to our previous games.

62 and game quite a lot. I have spent more time in MMORPG’s than in single player games, but I enjoy both. Given that the PC was invented when I was in college, and that I did not get my first one till 1997 when I was 40, some here have been in the gaming game much longer than me. My father, for instance, wrote some shareware games on 5 1/4 inch floppies back in the day (ran in DOS). He is 88 and just bought a new machine with a 47 inch 4K monitor. I guess the geekdom runs in the family.

Well, of course. But not the same game as you were 20s or 10s. A different range of group with different kind of game. Don’t you think it’s the same as what you eat now and then? I heard that some games enhance brain function as well, it works like a teraphy or some sort. Today, not every game requires you to press button A or B. I believe they’re completely accessible for anyone in any age. . Control how you play. . Got a spare time? Roast our games: http://rechronicle.itch.io See ya!

Thanks for the A2A :) Absolutely they do! I am only 21 myself, but I know for a fact that many of the people I've played with are much older. The people in their 50s and 60s who are still playing video games now will probably be the first generation to be gaming on their (natural) death beds. I'm sure there have already been some 90-year-olds smashing noobs in Battlefield, but they are very much the exception and not the rule. That's the great thing about games; you can still play them even when sports are no longer an option due to your age.

I'm 62, and I love playing games. Every morning I play a couple games of Mahjong and then some Entanglement. It's supposed to be good for the brain…I dislike crossword puzzles, and it's a great gauge of how troublesome my tremor is going to be that day. But computer games are my favorite, especially strategy games. Pretty sure I've played every version of CIV since the first. Remember when you had to make a special boot disk on floppy to get a DOS game to run? Good times!

Of course they do, age is a stupid concept when applied to video games. As I see it, as long as you’re mature and can act like a normal adult, you’re fine in here. 6 years old and you act like you’re ready for an office job? Welcome to the internet. 31 and you act like a spoiled brat throwing a tantrum every time they don’t get their way? Get the **** outta here.

Silly rabbit. Video games were invented and designed for “us”! We played the originals and often still do when we can find good old video games. I personally do not like most new games or the virtual reality ones. I can still beat most everyone at Space Invaders, Pac Man and several more. I'm 63.

Yes, I have known a couple of people that old that play video games. But I would say it’s uncommon. I suspect that there will be an even greater amount of old video game players as the years go by, since the old people of the future will have grown up on video games.

im 51 and im playing more than i did when i was 31 the amount of time invested in gaming fluctuates due to work schedules and the quality of television ..randomly there is nothing to watch between 2pm and 8pm and thanks to the invention of DVR’s fast forwarding through commercials and deliberately watching shows when the time to play is limited has increased gaming time immensely

They sure do! One of my all-time favorite customers was a retired guy. He’d come in anytime a third-person action RPG game came out. And he’d always want the same two things: The strategy guideWhatever version had the most content in it.He loved Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt, Horizon Zero Dawn, and a handful of other titles. He had been working since he was a young teenager and was very much enjoying his retirement.

Yes I play lots of games, mainly on the phone. I can remember the first time I used a mouse, back in the late 1980’s. It was to play a game and boy did I find it difficult to start with! I soon learned though and playing games has been a life long entertainment.

50 or 60 is a rookie number.  Try an 84–85-year-old woman who is not only alive 6 or 7 years older than your average American makes it to, but- Get this- Is STILL making Skyrim Let’s Play content. Her last video was uploaded YESTERDAY at time of writing, in fact. Mad respect to Tamriel’s favorite grandma. Here’s her channel. Shirley Curry

I’ve been playing since I first had a Commodore 64 in 1984 I think it was. To my knowledge I’m the oldest champion currently in Rocket League.I am currently researching to create a youtube channel directly for 50+ video gamers. Please let me know if you have any questions or content you would like me to cover. Thanks!

Yes they do. I’m aware of several people in their 50s who play games like Call of Duty and Battlefield. I’ve even heard of some gamers being in their 70s, and can still kick the crap out of “young whippersnappers.” Never underestimate the older generations. If they want to kick your arse, they will.

I’m not quite 50 yet (48) but I still play most days. My best mate is in his 50s and he plays EVERY day! I don’t plan on letting up any time soon as its a great way to relax so I would say people in their 50s definitely play. Oh and before you ask … I have a wife and 3 teenage kids and they come first (as does real life) but I still like to unwind with a game.
Yes, I plan to. I suspect I’ll be found dead at my computer having played a game that kicked me for being AFK too long. They’ll find a two liter of soda nearby as well. Sad, but true.

I played two pack solitaire on my computers from 50 upwards. Now at 75 I am very fond of Dominoes on iPad and still beat it. There is a Backgammon game I play occasionally. I have never liked shoot-em-up games and was delighted when my grandson began laying those on his own. I might be 75 on the outside but I play card games as if I was 20.

Sometimes. Usually, their reflexes aren’t that great, and sometimes carpal tunnel sets in and makes them unable to, but there have been a few people that old who manage to get it done. One notable example includes the grandma in that one meme image coming to a gamestop and talking about how she plays Assassin’s Creed to kill people.
Absolutely yes. People in their seventies also do. Oh, on second thoughts, maybe they don't play video games, but computer games, definitely. Peace
Yes we do! My husband joins our sons, nephews, and his brother online playing XBox all of the time. I enjoy Skyrim and Oblivion. I guess I should branch out, but eh I know what I like. 😎

Yes! Look at Skyrim Grandma! She is soooo cool and begins her you tube videos with “hello grandkids” They are putting her in the next game she is loved so much! A tribute! I plan on playing them until I die so yeah, old people play video games too!!
No we fart dust .
Yes, we do. Hubby and I are both in our early 50’s and we play GTA V OnlIne, Warframe, Assassin’s Creed (me), Deadpool (me) and Doom (hubby).

Simple answer, Why not? Games know no age, but of course situations would be different that they might not play horror or shooting games. They mostly tend to play casual games like candy crush, puzzle games and so.
I’m 48 years old now and still playing video games (but less than what I used to). Give me couple of more years and I will properly answer this question.
uhm really? Im mid 50’s + (at the time of this writing), That’s all I do in my spare time - well other hobbies as well, but gaming in my passion (check my profile) so a resounding Y E S ! ! ! !

There is a popular Twitch streamer named Sir Tony Ray (aka RSGoldandGlory) who plays Old School Runescape on a maxed account and is very active in the community. Maxing an account takes a very long time, it can take years. Sir Tony is 67 years old and has no plans to quit Runescape.
A2A. Absolutely!Gaming systems are much easier to use than a computer.It’s actually really good for seniors because it helps with hand-eye coordination.
well, I did when I was in my 50s and 60s
Yes lol I love the games and I am 61
Yes, we do. I’m 50 and I still play some video games (big fan of the Fallout and Elder Scrolls series).
I am 47 in a few weeks and I game all the time and intend to do it until the day die.
yes we do, and so do people in their 70s, and 80s.
